ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: There was a bit of confusion and a little disorganization in some of the activities and field trips. This was my only and very minor suggestion for improvement.I grew to like and respect Mike's teaching and mentorship more and more throughout the semester. He provided sophisticated analyses of forestry from operational and logistical and economic perspectives but also social and political considerations. He was knowledgeable about forestry laws in many states and had insightful critiques of federal policy and politics. I treasured his seasoned and reasonable criticism of forestry practices. I know I'll be thinking about his observations and judgments for years to come. And I look forward to staying in touch with Mike for years to come.
Question 9: The field trips were excellent. The last trip would have run even better had we had the paperwork figured out ahead of time.
One of the best courses I've ever taken. A great teacher, great material, great field work.

This class is so important. We have so few opportunities to learn about practical aspects and challenges of applied forestry, this course is a standout. It's also taught by a highly knowledgeable and well-rounded professional who embodies what he teaches. He draws from a range of professional experiences which helps us a lot in gaining a good perspective on the management challenges of forest operations. There is so much to learn in assessing the fine line between acceptable and damaging forest management, and it's impossible to do so without multiple extended field exercises, which this class provides. We came a little closer to understanding what was OK and what was not in harvest assessment, which is impossible to teach via textbook.
Mike's broad intelligence and his good naturedness.

1. Going into the field and discussing operations with practitioners2. Picking Mike's brain about FSC/SFI and other auditing of forests and forest management3. The last field exercise where we inventoried a parcel and then designed a harvest plan- this was a relatively simple exercise and FES needs more hands on practice like it4. Being held to a high standard on written reports- we had many reports to turn in and Mike set very high expectations for how those were put together and written. This emphasis on professionalism is very important.
Field work.
field time. felt more confident every time we went into the field.
Students can learn practical and real technique on forest operations.

The instructor - he's so excited about teaching this class, he really gets our needs and what we're learning (and what we're not) at FES and how to bring across the essential aspects of forest operations. He's an excellent teacher and visibly enjoys spending time with us, which is a great motivation.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: A warmer winter so we could have gotten out more.
1. Communication and organization. Everything came together well, but it would have been nice to have had more clarity on when things were due, and what we needed to prepare for each class.

possibly a mock final. to go in to the field and give a post harvest evaluation then share. the final was an informative process, but more practice before hand would be great. or spend some time going over trip reports comparing and contrasting.

I think the class could benefit from being taught more intensively - I know Mike's schedule is demanding, but it would be great to visit some operating pulp/paper/sawmill, to talk more about forest industry (where is all that wood going and what does it mean for management and harvest?) or an extended schedule - taught on occasional Fridays from September through March. Also, I felt like I was tat the verge of getting it - one or two more field trips, and I think I could have been much more comfortable with assessing the fine line between "good" and "bad" operations.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The TA was very helpful.

1. Mike is a little hard to get in touch with while he is traveling for work.I would appreciate him responding briefly but in a timely manner to emails. However, this is a price I am more than wiling to pay given FES's need to have more professionals teaching hands-on classes where we get out in the field.2. Shelby was always very available although her communication with Mike about assignments and class topics could have been better. I think that the TA-instructor relationship in this course is absolutely an essential one and in the future, we should be sure to have them communicate better so as to be on the same pageat all times.
Great.
good. TA was good at relaying logistics and planning trips.
The instructor is outside the school, but he is very accessible on email.
Excellent - quick to respond and very willing to help.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I'm an MF so this course is essential.

1. This is one of the most helpful and informative courses that I have taken while at FES. As we MFs learn about soils, silviculture, ecology and so forth, it is essential that we also learn how machinery and people operate in a forest during a harvest.This class provides us opportunities to discuss silviculture, forestry, forest industry and landowner objectives. It is a wonderful and absolutely essential part of the curriculum here at FES.
Want to be a forester, so perfectly.
fits very well into the MF program.
I could learn forestry from practical side.
It's key to the forestry program. I think it should be required. How can you manage forests if you don't learn about forest operations?

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn how to plan and assess forest operations.
This course is relevant to my goal, sustainable forest management.
It seemed natural - not taking it wasn't really an option.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Exceeded them.
Yes, absolutely.
Yes
It did well.
Absolutely.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes. One thing I would have liked to add would be a visit to a very poorly done harvest. We visited a lot of harvests, but thy were mostly well done and it was hard to get a sense for what is acceptable damage and what is not because we didn't see much unacceptable damage. Nobody wants to show off a poorly done harvest, but I would like us to have one to go look at and assess.
Yes
yes.
I did.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Our forest plan was done in groups, which was very helpful. I was glad to have a partner.
It is very helpful to talk through each operation with a group and to weigh the pros and cons of what we are seeing.
the group prescription and timber sale plan was a great experience.

It was helpful to work with a team and discuss management decisions in inventory and harvest plan. Talking about it really solidified our knowledge and forced us to assess a plan from various perspectives.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I'd recommend it to students who aren't thinking about it.

1. Spend some time on youtube watching machinery in operation before you take the class. This way you know what a feller buncher is before the first day of class.2. Demand clarity as far as when assignments are due.3. Go on the southern forestry field trip.4. Proofread each assignment repeatedly- Mike is a real stickler for any unprofessional grammatical errors.
Take with the Southern Field Trip - a knockout combo.
Ask questions as many as possible because the instructor has much practical knowledge that other instructors do not have.
Hmmm - ask Mike for more field trips.
